Particulars: Equipped (0001-0004) by the Compagnie van Verre of Amsterdam. Eerste Schipvaart under command of Kornelis de Houtman aboard the MAURITIUS. From 26-04 till 27-04 at Maio I.; from 04-08 till 11-08 in the Mosselbaai; from 13-09 till 07-10 in the Ampalazabaai; from 09-10 till 13-12 in S. Augustins Bay, where before departure 127 of the 249 men were still alive; 11-01 till 21-01 at Ste. Marie I.; from 23-01 till 12-02 in the Bay of Antongil. The AMSTERDAM was set on fire near Bawean, 11-01-1597.
Jan Dignumsz. died on 29-05-1595 and Mau was his successor.

Fleet (0005-0007) equipped by the Compagnie Ten Haeff of Middelburg under command of Gerard Le Roy aboard the ZON after the loss of the MAAN, which capsized while firing a salute near Dover. The fleet met the fleet of the Compagnie de Moucheron under command of Kornelis Houtman; 1 day at Maio I.; passing the Cape the 2 ships lost sight of each other.
Also mentioned as HOLLANDSE LEEUW.
The former DUIFJE of the Eerste Schipvaart.

The GELOOF met the fleet of Van Noort and joined in; tried for 9 months to sail through the Strait but failed to do so; returned with 36 men under Sebald de Weert, who succeeded Van Beuningen, to Holland and arrived in Goeree 13-07-1600.

Van Beuningen, vice-admiraal since 24-09-1598, aboard the LIEFDE was killed in S. Maria with 22 men and succeeded by Kwakernaak; the LIEFDE sailed via Hawaii and arrived in Japan 19-04-1600 with only 24/25 men. The Japanese confiscated the ship, but released the crew; later the ship was lost in Japanese waters.

The TROUW, under command of Balthasar de Cordes, who succeeded Jurriaan van Bokholt after his death 28-04-1599, arrived in Tidore, where the Portuguese laid an embargo on the ship and killed almost the whole crew.
Ran ashore at Ternate.
Squadron (0031-0034) of the fleet of Van Neck which sailed later under command of vice-admiraal Jakob Willekens aboard the MAURITIUS.
Fleet (0035-0038) under command of admiraal Pieter Both aboard the NEDERLAND and vice-admiraal Paulus van Caerden aboard the VERENIGDE LANDEN, equipped by the Nieuwe Brabantsche Compagnie.

Fleet (0039-0040) under command of admiraal Guilleaume Seneschel aboard the ZWARTE AREND, equipped by the Nieuwe Brabantsche Compagnie. From 01-07 till 06-07 at the Downs; from 12-07 till 14-07 at Portland; from 29-09 till 31-09 at Annabon.

Fleet (0041-0046) under command of Van Neck aboard the AMSTERDAM and Foreest aboard the DORDRECHT, equipped by the Oude Oostindische Compagnie. From 01-10 till 10-10 at Annabon whereafter the fleet was divided into 2 squadrons: 1 squadron under command of Van Neck, consisted of the AMSTERDAM, the GOUDA, the DELFT and the other under command of Foreest, consisted of the LEIDEN, the DORDRECHT and the HAARLEM.
Left behind at Patani in September 1603 as unseaworthy.
Fleet (0047-0050) of the Verenigde Zeeuwsche Compagnie. July 17th. at Anjouan; August 14th at Ceylon. Total number of deaths 5.
Fleet (0051-0053) under command of admiraal Wolfert Harmensz. aboard the GELDERLAND and Hans Hendriksz. Bouwer, equipped by the Oude Oostindische Compagnie. From 27-09 till 20-10 at Mauritius.
With the death of Le Fort (26-06) the RAM was sold to the V.O.C. and put under the command of Sebald de Weert (see 0067-69).

Squadron (0067-0069) under the command of vice-admiraal Sebald de Weert aboard the ZIERIKZEE of the fleet of Van Warwyck. The three ships of Zeeland preceded the rest of the fleet. Took on provisions in the Bay of Antongil.
According to Commelin the master was Willem Lok. The ship stayed in the Indies.
Stayed in the Indies.
Took on provisions for about one month at Mauritius. Mooilieven was succeeded by Jan Konnelisz. van Avenhorn.

Fleet under adm. Steven van der Hagen aboard the GEÜNIEERDE PROVINCIËN and vice-adm. Kornelis Bastiaansz. aboard the DORDRECHT (0082-0093). 10-01 till 12-02 at Plymouth; 10-03 till 30-05 at Maio Island, where the DORDRECHT and the ZEELANDIA joined the fleet; 30-06 the Cape rounded; 22-06 till 10-07 in the Verhagensbaai; 28-07 till 15-08 at Mozambique, the DELFT, the DUIFJE and the ENKHUIZEN sailed 5 days later and rejoined the fleet at the Comoro Islands; 19-08 till 27-08 at the Comoro Islands, 29-09 till 14-10 before Goa to harrass the Portuguese; 12-12 the DELFT set sail between Ceylon and Sumatra for Atjeh. The MEDEMBLIK and the HOP VAN HOLLAND left the fleet for Mauritius to look for the missing ship WACHTER. Forced by a contrary wind the ships arrived in the Bay of Antongil, where the ALKMAAR was found, deserted and destroyed by shipworm. The HOF VAN HOLLAND took over the cargo and sailed back home, the MEDEMBLIK proceeded to Bantam.
Sent to Mauritius to collect ebony. According to Commelin departure 20-05-1605. At Mauritius 22-05-1606 (see 5068 and 5069). Destroyed by fire on the coast of Coromandel (1610).
According to Mac Leod the master was Abraham Mathijsz.
18-08-1606 burnt in action before Malacca.

Fleet (0095-0106) under adm. Kornelis Matelieff aboard the ORANJE. On 14-05-1605 the 7 ships of Amsterdam arrived in Zeeland; on 24-5 they departed with the 2 ships of Zeeland. From 04 till 19-07 off Maio I. and 07 till 15-09 off Annabon; from 01 till 27-01 1606 at Mauritius. At 06-01 the WITTE LEEUW and the AMSTERDAM were sent for Atjeh under vice-adm. Olivier de Vivere. From 25-03 till 05-04 at the Nicobar Islands; from 01-05 the fleet was before Johore where it started operations against the Portuguese. The ERASMUS, the PROVINCIËN and probably the EENDRACHT departed not before 30-05 from the Maas. The first 2 ships joined Matelieff on 14-07-1607 off Malacca, the EENDRACHT was sent for Mauritius to collect ebony. In August 1610 this ship was destroyed by fire on the coast of Coromandel. The ship probably never formed part of the fleet of Matelieff. The GROTE ZON and the KLEINE ZON stayed in the Indies and were broken up at Banda.

Fleet (0107-0114) under adm. Paulus van Caerden aboard the BANDA and vice-adm. Adriaan Maartensz. aboard the WALCHEREN. The total number of those on board was 1060. From 23-05 till 03-06 on the roadstead of the isle of Wight, the 3 ships from Zeeland arrived here 25-05; 29-03 at Mocambique, where they started operations against the Portuguese. When leaving, 26-05, the ZIERIKZEE ran aground and was lost; the mainfleet was therefore unable to sail before June, 29th; from 08-06 till 17-07 at the Comoro I; from 04-08 till 26-08 again at Mozambique and 02-10 at Goa.
Riding at anchor off Ternate in 1608, the ship was lost due to bad weather.
The ship was forced by bad weather to take refuge in the harbour of Vlissingen, July 19th and was lost, making its way out July 20th.
Captured by the Spaniards off Manila, 25-04-1610.
Captured by the Spaniards off Manilla, 25-04-1610.

Fleet (0118-0130) under adm. Pieter Willemsz. Verhoeff aboard the GEÜNIEERDE PROVINClËN and vice-adm. Frans Hendriksz. Wittert aboard the MIDDELBURG. The 3 Zeeland ships and the mainfleet met at Maio I. February 1608; from 15-05 till 02-06 at St. Helena; 28-06 somewhere in the regions off the Cape; from 28-06 till 23-08 the fleet started operations against the Portuguese at Mozambique; from 18-09 till 02-10 off Goa.
May 22th 1609 Frans Jakobsz. de Vries was murdered by the inhabitants of Banda.
The ship was despatched to bring news of the forthcoming Twelve Years' Truce; stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near the Maledive Islands.
Destined to explore the North-East passage to the Indies; discovered Hudson Bay and returned 07-12 in Dartmouth. Further information see I'Honore Naber.

Fleet (0135-0142) under Gouverneur-Generaal Pieter Both aboard the WAPEN VAN AMSTERDAM. The 3 Zeeland ships met the mainfleet near the Isle of Wight at 01-02; from 21-02 till 27-02 at Maio I.; at 09-06 a storm scattered the fleet; from 19-09 till 16-10 the WAPEN VAN AMSTERDAM took on provisions at Mauritius.
The CEYLON lost sight of the fleet 03-07.
Lost sight of the fleet; from 24-07 till 03-08 in the 'Verhagens-baai'; from 29-08 till 27-09 at Mayotte.

Fleet (0143-0144) under the command of Hendrik Brouwer aboard the RODE LEEUW MET PIJLEN sailed the southern passage for the first time (latitude ca. 36° south), which was made obligatory in 1616. The GOUDA was captured by the Spaniards near Tidore, 04-05-1612.
Capsized near Makian 31-01-1613; 15 survivors.
Ran aground near Surat and lost, 17-07-1617.
Lost sight of the mainfleet after a heavy storm 05-07 but joined the fleet again at 22-10; in the meanwhile took on provisions in the Bay of Antongil.
Lost in the Indies 02-10-1614.
Also mentioned as ZEELAND or OUD-ZEELAND.
Reprovisioned in St. Lucia Bay. The ship stayed in the Indies and was laid up ca. 1620-1621.

Fleet (0169-0170) under the command of Jasper van Surk aboard the MIDDELBURG. May 4th at Maio I.; August 10th the ZEELANDIA disappeared from sight and the MIDDELBURG reprovisioned in St. Lucia Bay. Later the MIDDELBURG was lost near Surat, 19-07-1617.

Fleet (0172-0175) under command of Gouverneur-Generaal Gerard Reynst and admiraal Steven van der Hagen aboard the WAPEN VAN AMSTERDAM. From 29-09 till 05-10 at S. Vincente; January 10th. at Cape Lopez; from 21-02 till 02-03 at Annabon; May 31th. somewhere off the Cape; from 13-06 till 21-07 at the Comoro Islands.
According to Coolhaas the ship arrived at Bantam 16-01-1615. The ship stayed in the Indies and ran aground in the river Andragiri 19-09-1615.

Fleet (0177-0182) under command of Adriaan Woutersz. Stoop (@+@ 26-11-1615) aboard the VLISSINGEN. The VLISSINGEN had a difficult voyage; 19-12 rounding the Cape the ship sailed north too early; 18-11-1615 (!) it encountered the WALCHEREN, the ENGEL and the AMSTERDAM.
From April 1615 till May 1615 at Mauritius to collect the cargo of the wrecked GELDERLAND (6007).
Left Madagascar 15-02-1615; from April 1615 till 01-05-1615 at Mauritius.
Burst in the battle of Manila, 16-04-1617.
From 08-01 till 22-01-1615 at Maio Island.
Reprovisioned in the Bay of Antongil.
Reprovisioned at Cabo de Lopez Gonsalvez 20-09-1615; laid up in Batavia, 1621.
Captured by the English near Bantam, 15-12-1618.
Renamed ZUIDER EENDRACHT; capsized off Bantam, May 1620. The HOORN was destroyed by fire in Port Desire, 19-12-1615. Further information see Engelbrecht and Van Herwerden.
From 21-02 till 04-03 Maio Island; 28-03-1616 departure from Cabo de Lopez Gonsalvez; from 19-06 till 09-07 at Annabon.
From 21-02 till 04-03 at Maio Island; from 27-03 till 11-05 at Cape Lopez; landed on the West Coast of Australia (27ø South), October 25th.
Reprovisioned at Annabon; via ' Verhagensbaai' to the Primeira Islands, and back to the 'Verhagensbaai.'
Reprovisioned in the Gulf of Guinea, at the Cape and at Mauritius.
Reprovisioned in the St. Lucia Bay.
Reprovisioned in the St. Lucia Bay.
Stayed in the Indies and was wrecked on the shore of China, September 1622.
Stayed in the Indies and laid up between 1620-1621.
April 19th St. Paul sighted by the Dutch for the first time. May llth on the west coast of Australia. The ship stayed in the Indies.
Stayed in the Indies; wrecked on the African coast 21-06-1622.
Fleet (0223-0232) under command of Frederik de Houtman aboard the DORDRECHT and Jakob Dedel. Total number of those on board: seamen 1725; soldiers 675.
From 25-02 till 02-03 at Brava Island. The ship stayed in the Indies.
Forced by heavy weather in the Bay of Biscay the GOEDE HOOP returned to Zeeland and departed again 13-05-1619; from 14-08 till 21-08 at Cape Lopez.

From 07-01 till 26-01 at Plymouth, where 3 man deserted; from 25-02 till 02-03 at Bravo Island; from 03-07 till 17-07 near St. Maria (Madagascar). The ship stayed in the Indies and was wrecked on the Westcoast of Sumatra. Also mentioned as NIEUW ZEELAND.
June 19th on the west coast of Australia (37ø 20' South); the ship stayed in the Indies.
From 20-08 till 01-09 at Cape Lopez; from 08-02 till 11-02 at Annabon.

From 02-10 till 11-10 at Cape Lopez; February 5th with the GOUDEN LEEUW to the 'Dasseneiland' and St. Helena; from 15-02 till 25-02 at St. Helena. The ship stayed in the Indies and was lost near Sucatara; crew and cargo were saved.
Forced to return to Zeeland, 11-06-1619, but sailed again shortly afterwards.
Lost on a return voyage from Siam or Japan, 1627.
Reprovisioned at Annabon. The ship stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Surat, between 31-10-1627 and 31-10-1628.
Stayed in the Indies and wrecked in the river Andragiry, September 1622.
Stayed in the Indies and lost between Amboina and Batavia, 1621.
Stayed in the Indies and probably laid up.
Departure from S. Vincente 31-01-1621. The ship stayed in the Indies and ran ashore near Arakan, 1628.
Via Plymouth; from 10-03 till 24-03 at S. Vincente. The ship stayed in the Indies and was broken up in Batavia between 31-10-1627 and 31-10-1628.
Departure from Plymouth 31-01-1621; from 10-03 till 24-03 at S. Vincente. The ship stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near Formosa, 19-07-1623.
Stayed in the Indies and broken up, 1629.
Stayed in the Indies; captured by the Chinese I Kwan in 1627, but returned in 1628 and laid up in 1629.
Via the Gulf of Guinea and the west coast of Australia.

After its departure March 1624 forced by adverse winds and leakage to return to Surat, where the cargo was brought aboard the SCHOONHOVEN. The VREDE stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near Hirado, September 1631.
Stayed in the Indies.
Stayed in the Indies.
Stayed in the Indies and broken up in Batavia between 31-10-1627 and 31-10-1628.
21-07 on the west coast of Australia (27ø).
Stayed in the Indies.

Nassausche Vloot (0296-0307) under command of admiraal Jacques l'Hermite aboard the AMSTERDAM and vice admiraal Huigen Schapenham aboard the DELFT, who succeeded l'Hermite after his death before Callao, 02-06-1624; equipped to attack the Spaniards on the West coast of South America; sailed through Strait Le Maire. Further information, see Voorbeijtel Cannenburg. According to this author the master of the ORANJE was called Laurens Jansz. Quirijnen.
Daghregister mentions WAPEN VAN AMSTERDAM.
Pieter Kornelsz. Hartloop succeeded, on September 9th 1624, Meindert Egbertsz., who died 28-08-1624, as master of the AREND. The AREND was sold to the V.O.C. and lost near Cape Mauritius.
Pieter Kornelisz. Hartloop who became master of the AREND was succeeded by Pieter Hendriksz. The ship stayed in the Indies, under commission of the V.O.C. and was lost near the Moluccas.
Pieter Harmensz. Slobbe who became master of the MAURITIUS, September 1th 1623, was succeeded by Salomon Willemsz. The ship was sold to the V.O.C. and stayed in the Indies.
Jakob Adriaansz. van Duin, who died 28-08-1623 in Sierra Leone, was succeeded by Pieter Harmensz. Slobbe, 01-09-1623. The ship was sold to the V.O.C.
The ship stayed in the Indies. According to Daghregister departure from the Maas, 31-12-1624.
Stayed in the Indies.
Stayed in the Indies.
Reprovisioned at S. Tomé.
Because of a storm, the SCHIEDAM missed the Cape, and took on provisions for several weeks at St. Mary Island.
Wrecked on the roadstead of Texel, 05-07-1625.
Forced by a storm to take refuge in Falmouth, leaving Falmouth 21-02-1626, leaving behind 35 deserters. During the voyage 1 man was taken on board.
Stayed in the Indies and wrecked on the coast of China, 22-09-1631.
Stayed in the Indies and broken up.
Lost in the river Chincheu on the coast of China; 07-10-1633; according to Mac Leod lost near Amoy, 05-02-1629.
Reprovisioned in Sierra Leone, June 17th. The ship stayed in the Indies and was burnt in the river Chincheu.
Reprovisioned in Sierra Leone, June.
Sailed again from Goeree, 11-11-1626.
Stayed in the Indies; ran aground and was destroyed by fire on the coast of Formosa, 28-06-1633. According to Mac Leod 08-11-1633.
From 12-04 till 16-04 at Maio Island; the ship stayed in the Indies.
From 12-04 till 16-04 at Maio Island; from 22-09 till 07-10 at Anjouan; from 27-11 till 17-12 at Gale.
From 12-04 till 16-04 at Maio Island.
Achterom and via Maio Isl. Stayed in the Indies and was lost near Mauritius, 1630.
Wrecked on the Needles of Wight, 23-10-1627.
From November 1627 till 07-01-1628 at Maio Island.
November 1627 at Maio Island; the ship stayed in the Indies and was probably laid up.
From November 1627 till 07-01-1628 at Maio Island.
Reprovisioned at St. Lucia Bay.
Via Australia; stayed in the Indies and probably laid up.
Stayed in the Indies.
Departure from Sierra Leone, 07-10-1628.
Stayed in the Indies.
Destroyed by fire on the coast of the Coromandel, 11-02-1630.
From 03-11-1628 till 04-05-1629 in Zeeland.
Wrecked on the Wallabi Group, 04-06-1629. Wreck has been discovered (see H. Edwards).
From 28-01 till 17-02-1629 in the Downs; March 23th till 24th at St. Antao.
From 28-01 till 17-02-1629 in the Downs; wrecked at St. Antao, 24-03-1629.
From 28-01 till 17-02-1629 in the Downs; from 23-03 till 04-04 on the Cape Verde I; via Martin Vaz. The ship stayed in the Indies; was destroyed by fire in the river Chincheu, 22-10-1633.
Blown up near Djambi, fighting the Portuguese, 05-04-1630. From 28-01 till 17-02 in the Downs; from 22-03 till 17-02 on the Cape Verde I.
Blown up near Djambi, fighting the Portuguese, 06-05-1630. According to Mac Leod 07-05-1629.
Destroyed by fire in Strait Sunda, 14-11-1629.
Stayed in the Indies.
From the Downs 25-03 back to Zeeland; from Zeeland 26-06-1630; from 04-07 till 10-07 at Cape Frio.
March 25th. from the Downs; from 04-07 till 10-04 in Brazil.
Sailed to the equator but returned because of bad trimming and was captured by a Dunkirk privateer.
Via Sierra Leone.
Captured a Portuguese jacht during the voyage; wrecked on the coast of Cochin China, 1635.
Stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near the river Patrapa, 19-02-1637.
No ports of call.
From 30-01 till 06-02 at S. Vincente, stayed in the Indies.
Stayed in the Indies; ran ashore in Strait Doeriam, May 1641 and was burnt.
No ports of call at all. 03-03 is the date of the second departure.
No ports of call at all; stayed in the Indies and was laid up 1640.
May 3rd at Maio I.
Back to Vlissingen, sailed again January 28th; from 30-01 till 22-02 off the Isle of Wight; from 20-03 till 25-03 at S. Vincente; stayed in the Indies.
Captured by a Dunkirk privateer.
No ports of call; stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near the 'Duizend eilanden'.
No ports of call; stayed in the Indies and was laid up, 1646.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Batavia, 1644.
Via the Saldanha Bay.
Reprovisioned at S. Vincente.
Reprovisioned in Sierra Leone; stayed in the Indies.
Stayed in the Indies.
Stayed in the Indies.
Stayed in the Indies and wrecked on a reef between Colombo and Negombo, 01-01-1640.
Stayed in the Indies and was set on fire by the Portuguese off Goa, 04-01-1638.
Via Cape Verde, departure June 1st.
0464-0479 departed with 2557 men; death-toll 123 (Coolhaas I, 556). From 22-01-1636 till 16-02-1636 in the Wielingen. July 5th on the west coast of Australia, 25° S.
From 22-01 till 16-02-1636 in the Wielingen; the ship stayed in the Indies; laid up 1645.
From 22-01 till 16-02-1636 in the Wielingen.
From 22-01 till 16-02-1636 in the Wielingen; the ship stayed in the Indies and ran ashore, coming from Taiwan on the coast of 'Champa', 1637; according to Mac Lead in the Bay of Padaran, 29-10-1636.
From 22-01 till 16-02-1636 in the Wielingen; coming from Banda the OTTER was wrecked upon a reef south of Buton, 1643; according to Coolhaas the crew was murdered 07-09-1643.
From 22-01 till 16-02-1636 in the Wielingen.
From 22-01 till 16-02-1636 in the Wielingen; the ship stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Batavia, 1644.
According to Daghregister 1636, 153, departure 16-02-1636.
No ports of call; stayed in the Indies and was wrecked, 1650.
No ports of call.
No ports of call.
Via Sierra Leone, reprovisioning there for 8 days, leaving 19-07-1636; stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near Pulicat, 13-10-1638.
Via Sierra Leone, reprovisioning there for 8 days, leaving 19-07-1636.
0480-0493 (except 0486) departed with 2669 men, arrived with 2511, amongst whom 637 soldiers; death-toll 158 (Coolhaas, I, 598).
Sailed on the shallows off Brouwershaven and was wrecked; crew and cargo were saved.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up, probably 1646.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up in 1648.
0494-0509 (except 0508) departed with 2306 men; death-rate 263 (Coolhaas I, 730). Stayed in the Indies and was lost in action against the Spaniards near the Philippines.
Stayed in the Indies and was foundered on the rocks, east of Banka, June 1647.
Via Mauritius; stayed in the Indies and ran ashore at Solor, 10-04-1642.
14 men killed at the Cape; the ship stayed in the Indies and was lost in the Pescadores, 31-12-1639.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Batavia, 1652.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Malacca, 1653.
Ran ashore at Taiwan, 21-06-1639.
From 25-05 till 31-05 at S. Vicente.
From 25-05 till 31-05 at S. Vicente, via Mauritius; the ship stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Batavia, 1648.
Via Mauritius, arrival December 20th., departure 5 weeks later.
Via Mauritius.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Amboina, December 1651.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Batavia, February 1650.
Via Mauritius; stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Batavia, 1652.
Wrecked on a reef off Goa, fighting the Portuguese and was lost, 06-12-1639.
Wrecked on the S.E. coast of Madagascar, 29-08-1639.
Wrecked off Sierra Leone, June or July 14th; crew and cargo were saved.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up, 1649.
Stayed in the Indies and ran ashore on Lombok, 27-12-1642.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Batavia, 1652.
Stayed in the Indies and was wrecked in the river Ganges, 10-08-1648.
Stayed in the Indies and scuttled in bad condition in the Philippines, 09-11-1647.

Stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Batavia, 1648.
From 12-02 till 26-02 at Mauritius; the ship stayed in the Indies and was lost south of the Isle of Champello.
Stayed in the Indies, laid up in Batavia and sold, 15-02-1659.

Via Maio Island and Mauritius.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up, 1649.

Stayed in the Indies and was lost south of the Isle of Champello, 26-11-1641.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up, 1648.
Stayed in the Indies and was laid up in the Moluccas, 1652. According to Schoute 234 men were on board.
Stayed in the Indies and was used at Onrust, 1653.

Stayed in the Indies; was wrecked on a reef south of Celebes, 04-03-1650.
From 21-07 till 31-10-1641 back in Goeree.
Via Pernambuco; the ship stayed in the Indies, was wrecked on the roadstead of Batavia and broken up, January 1657.

According to Aanw. 1891/19e departure 07-03-1642; returned to Texel and sailed again 30-09-1642. Then, having lost its masts back to Texel in October, sailing again 02-11-1642. The ship stayed in the Indies and was burnt in Bengal, 09-10-1650.
Stayed in the Indies; on a reef south of Celebes, 04-03-1650.
Stayed in the Indies and was lost in a sea battle in the Bay of Tigaol, 01-08-1646.
Stayed in the Indies and was broken up in Ternate, 1646. According to Uitloopboek, 4389, wrecked on a reef in Strait Banka. According to Schoute 35 men had died at arrival.
Via Mauritius September 6th, 1642; stayed in the Indies and was broken up in Surat, 1649.
Wrecked near Majoe, 1653.

Wrecked on a reef in the Pescadores 27-10-1644; crew, except 1 man, and cargo saved.
Via the Isle of Wight, departure 21-02-1643; stayed in the Indies and was laid up in Batavia, 1648.

From 15-06 till 25-06 at S. Vincente; from 09-11 till 15-11 in Sierra Leone with 82 deaths and 15 healthy men. Via the west coast of Australia (Suytlandt) for an inquiry concerning the VERGULDE DRAAK. In 1668/69 sold to a Portuguese citizen of Batavia. Master became Joost Jansz. van Serooskerke.
From 10 till 27-02 back at the Wielingen. Missed the Cape because of a storm. Via Mauritius, departure: 20-08-1657.

Master: Nesse, Andries v. after the Cape: Dalen, Pieter v.
Particulars: The men who embarked at the Cape came from the HASSELT and the MARIA. The master, Andries van Nesse, was dismissed because of adultery with the wife of the onderkoopman. According to Van Riebeek, II, 153, the ship departed from the Wielingen with 263 men.
Laid up in 1661. At the Cape 31 seafarers and 45 soldiers were taken over by the ENKHUIZEN.
See the ROTTERDAM (0874).
Via Falmouth: one man deserted there. Until the Cape the voyage was severely delayed by calm and adverse winds. The ship was sold in 1673.

During the voyage Andries Wolf died; Jan Jansz. Vlodrop succeeded him as master. The 16 'passengers' who embarked at the Cape were slaves, 12 of them arrived at Batavia.
A Portuguese slave ship carrying 250 slaves was captured off Brazil. At the arrival at the Cape about 80 of them had died and many were ill; some 100 slaves arrived at Batavia.
For four weeks at Tristan da Cunha because of calm. Via Cape Leewin.
Sailing to Canton in 1659, the GEELMUIDEN was wrecked.

The 'passengers' who embarked at the Cape, were 6 Portuguese prisoners, 1 female slave and 2 children.

Particulars: Via Faeroe Islands. The ship stayed there for two months; ten seafarers enlisted. The ship brought commandeur Van Kwaalberge to the Cape.

Via S. Vincente, arrival on 14-10-1666.

3 soldiers became seafarers. Acc. to K.A.1158 Hendrik Boudewijnse was master. At S. Vincente on 28-12-1666 till 25-01-1667. Coming from Persia the ship was wrecked at Baios de Padua on 05-07-1668, with 27 men drowned.

Via Texel, departure on 06-06-1667. Via Sierra Leone, 24-08 till 02-09-1667. At the Cape one seaman and five soldiers came on board as prisoners (counted as passengers). They were probably released at Batavia. The ship was sold in 1673.

The master died near the Abrolhos, and was succeeded by Kornelis Mathall. At Bravo I. there was a mutiny of some soldiers. Four soldiers were thrown overboard, one seaman and five soldiers went to the MEERMAN (1068). One child was born. The ship was wrecked near the isle of Galle (Bengal) on 08-08-1671.

The ship was met in the Channel by two Turkish privateers, but escaped. Via S. Tiago. The ship was wrecked at Tuticorin on 22-02-1682.

The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 31-08-1678.
According to Daghregister 1670 the ship departed from Texel on 17-12-1669. Via the Cape Verde Islands.
The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia in 1675.

Acc. to Uitloopboek 4389 the ship departed on 31-10-1670. The ship ran ashore east of Madura Island on 31-08-1677; 18 men were drowned.
Acc. to Uitloopboek 4389 the ship departed on 31-10-1670. Via S. Vincente (03 till 08-11-1670). The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 31-01-1678.

Acc. to K.A. 3984 the ship departed on 23-12-1670. Via Duins. Acc. to Daghregister 1671 the ship arrived at the Cape on 05-03-1671.

Via Falmouth, where 4 seafarers and 2 soldiers deserted and 1 seaman signed on. Acc. to Daghregister 1671 the ship left the Cape on 16-06-1671.
Via Falmouth, where 3 seafarers deserted, and via False Bay (arrival on 25-05-1671), where 1 seaman and 2 soldiers were left behind. The ship was laid up and gallows were erected on the deck. (1680).
The ship was wrecked in the river Ganges on 05-12-1674.
Via Falmouth. From the men who went ashore at the Cape, 7 ran away.
Via Falmouth. The ship was wrecked at the island Fortuin near Sumatra in November 1677.
Because of adverse winds via Duins (14-01 till 11-02-1671). Two children were born during the voyage. At the Cape 6 men ran away; Acc. to Daghregister 1671 the ship left the Cape on 06-06-1671.
Via Duins, 15-01 till 11-02-1671.
The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 01-02-1680.

Via S. Tiago. Sold at Batavia on 06-01-1685.

Via Wight (29-09) and S. Tiago. See also 1198. The ship was laid up in 1679 and the hull was sold on 18-01-1680.
Via S. Tiago. Three children were born during the voyage; Acc. to Daghregister 1672 the ship left the Cape on 27-02-1672.
Via S. Tiago. On the return voyage in 1674 the ship carried French prisoners of war. The ship was restored to the Company on 21-04-1676.
Acc. to K.A. 3985 departure on 17-12-1671. Via Guinea, S. Tomé, Annabon, Ascension and Corisco. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 16-06-1685.
Via S. Tiago.
Via Portland, where 3 seafarers deserted. Laid up and sold at Batavia on 12-05-1681.
Acc. to Daghregister 1672 the ship left the Cape on 29-02-1672. In 1674 the ship was wrecked off S.Tomé.
The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 16-06-1685.

Acc. to Daghregister 1672 the ship left the Cape on 30-05-1672.
The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 22-03-1681.
The ship was laid up at Malacca, in April 1682.

Hubert Hugo was commandeur. 
From 30-05 till 17-12-1672 the ship sailed to Mozambique, Mayotte and Madagascar; 2 seafarers deserted at Mozambique. Via Mauritius from 15-01 till April/May 1673. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 29-08-1684. *These figures refer to the Cape and Mauritius.
The master died on 04-07-1672; he was succeeded by Marten Binkershoek.
The ship was taken by the English.

The ship brought the news of the war with England and France to the Cape and also the Heren XVII's order to do as much damage to the French and English as possible; the LIJSTER (1191) went to Batavia with the same message.

The ZUIDPOLSBROEK, KATTENBURG (1227) and VRIJHEID (1229) under command of Jakob Geus left the Cape for St. Helena on 10-12-1672, arrived on 30-12 and took the island from the English on 12-01-1673. They left a garrison (± 100 men) and departed on 11-03-1673. The ZUIDPOLSBROEK arrived at the Cape with one soldier, taken prisoner at St. Helena. 
The ship was laid up at Batavia. 
*These figures refer to the Cape and St. Helena.

See 1226. After departure from St. Helena no call at the Cape. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia. on 16-07-1677. 
*These figures refer to the Cape and St. Helena.
See 1226. After departure from St. Helena no call at the Cape. One child was born during the voyage. *These figures refer to the Cape and St. Helena.
The ship met the return fleet under command of Arnoud van Overbeke (5627-5641) near the Shetland Islands on 25-07-1672. Via Sierra Leone.

Via Bergen in Norway (on 05-10-1672) because of loss of the main mast, where 5 seafarers and 7 soldiers deserted. Via S. Tiago, where 7 soldiers enlisted. 2 children were born during the voyage. Acc. to Daghregister 1673 the ship left the Cape on 21-04-1673.
Via S. Vincente. One child was born during the voyage. Acc. to Daghregister 1673 the ship left the Cape on 21-04-1673; acc. to Van Dam I, 491 built by Enkhuizen.
The master died on 30-01-1673; he was succeeded by Willem van der Hop. The ship left the Cape on 21-04-1673, acc. to Daghregister 1673. It was wrecked 50 miles east of the Cape on 23-08-1673.

On 29-12-1672 there was a fight with an English frigate (1 dead and 8 wounded), but the ship escaped on the third day. During this voyage the master and nearly all the officers died. Acc. to Daghregister 1673 the ship left the Cape on 26-05-1673.
Via S. Vincente.
Acc. to Daghregister 1673 the ship left the Cape on 21-04-1673. The ship sank at Palembang on 28-09-1682.
Lost near England in February 1673.
Via S. Tiago. The ship was sold at Surat in 1680.
Via S. Tiago.
Via S. Tiago. The ship was laid up at Batavia on 03-09-1680.
Via S. Tiago. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 29-09-1685.

Via S. Vincente, where 4 seafarers and 1 soldier stayed behind.
The ship was blown up at the roadstead of Batavia in 1690.
Via S. Tiago. Acc. to Daghregister 1674 the ship arrived at the Cape on 10-04-1674. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia in July 1687.

Particulars: Via S. Tiago. Acc. to Daghregister 1674 one passenger disembarked at the Cape instead of embarked.
Via S. Tiago, where 2 seafarers deserted.
Via S. Tiago. One soldier turned out to be a woman.
Via Tenerife, where 4 seafarers deserted, and via S. Tiago.
Via Cape Verde.

Original departure on 10-02-1673, but returned two months later. Via S. Tiago. The ship brought the news of peace with England.
Via S. Tiago. In 1674 the ship capsized near the Maldive Islands. The master and the crew arrived safely at Cochin.
The ship was laid up at Batavia on 03-01-1688.
Acc. to Daghregister 1674 the ship departed from Texel on 29-06-1674. It was laid up and sold at Batavia on 29-08-1684.
Via Cape Lopez, Sao Tomé and Saldanha Bay. Acc. to Daghreg. 1675 the ship departed on 10-02-1675 from the Cape.
The passenger who embarked at the Cape was a prisoner; he died during the voyage.
A conspiracy of seven men to sail the ship to Brazil was discovered; four of them were hanged at the Cape, the other three got a sentence of 20 years penal servitude.
The ship was laid up at Ceylon in 1687.
One child was born during the voyage and one soldier turned out to be a woman.
The number of the shipowner's men is unknown.

Particulars: Via S. Tiago. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 08-01-1683.

Via Plymouth (15 days), where 6 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted, 1 soldier was enlisted.

Via Plymouth (15 days) and S. Tiago. Acc. to K.A. 3989 the passenger did arrive at Batavia.

Via Plymouth where 7 seafarers deserted on 13-02-1675. The master died during the voyage and was buried at S. Tiago. He was succeeded by Laurens Verbeek. The ship was wrecked at Coromandel in January 1680.
Via S. Tiago, where one seaman deserted.
The ship was laid up at Batavia in April 1690.

Via Plymouth (departure 14-09-1675) because of abroken mast and adverse winds. 102 seafarers, 55 soldiers and 5 passengers deserted or disembarked on Plymouth. 83 new seafarers and 3 soldiers were enlisted.

Via S. Vincente.
Via S. Vincente, where one seaman was put ashore.
Via S. Vincente. During the voyage one seaman was enlisted.
Via Vlissingen (departure 18-05-1675). The ship was laid up and sold in 1682.

Via Duins (departure on 17-01-1676), where one seaman deserted and one was enlisted. At the Cape 6 seafarers and 2 passengers disembarked.
Via Duins (departure on 17-01-1676). The ship was laid up and sold on 04-03-1684.
Via Duins (departure on 17-01-1676). At the Cape 5 seafarers went over to the MUIDERBERG (1308).

Via S. Tiago. The ZIERIKZEE carried part of the cargo of the SINT LAURENS (1313) to Batavia.

Because of leakage the ship had to return to the Maas; second departure on 27-06-1676. During the voyage the ship was unsuccesfully attacked by four French ships. Laid up on 31-01-1681 and sold in February 1683.

Via S. Tiago, where one soldier was enlisted.
During the voyage the ship was unsuccesfully attacked by four French ships. Via Cape Verde.
Via S. Vincente. Laid up and sold on 22-03-1683.
Via S. Vincente. At Colombo on 19-06-1677.

Via S. Tiago, where 22 men deserted. No call at the Cape because of danger of war. At Colombo on 29-07-1677.

Via England, where 8 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted. 9 seafarers and 2 soldiers were pressed. The master was succeeded by Leendert Laurensz. No call at the Cape because of danger of war. One seaman turned out to be a woman.
Via Falmouth, where 2 seafarers deserted and 5 seafares and 4 soldiers were pressed. No call at the Cape because of danger of war. Laid up and sold on 10-06-1683.

Via S. Vincente. The ship sailed to Ceylon because of leakage and the loss of topmasts (28-08 till 26-10-1678), where 8 seafarers and 63 soldiers left the ship and 37 seafarers, 11 soldiers and 5 passengers, came on board.

Via S.Tiago. Orders were received for a slave trade to Madagascar and to bring the slaves to the west coast of Sumatra. Via Ceylon (24-11 till 05-12-1681) and Sumatra. Acc. to Daghreg. 1682 the ship arrived at Batavia on 02-09-1682.

Back at Texel from 28-05 till 24-06-1731. One seafarer ran away; one seafarer went to the HUIS TE MARQUETTE (2847). The ship stayed at the Saldanha Bay from 13-01 till 14-02-1732. Acc. to K.A. 2100 the master was Klaas Meelhoop; he probably succeeded Jan Molentijn during the voyage. The ship was wrecked on 01-06-1734.

The ship was from 12-12-1731 till 12-01-1732 at St. Helena and from 02-02 till 14-02-1732 at Saldanha Bay. Acc. to K.A. 2100 Willem de Wijs was the master: he probably succeeded Pieter Knollendam. Laid up at Batavia on 19-04-1737.
From 07-07-1731 till 16-07-1731 at S. Tiago: 3 seafarers and 4 soldiers ran away. Laid up at Batavia on 22-04-1738.
From 08-07 till 16-07-1731 at S. Tiago; 1 soldier deserted; from 01-12-1731 till 15-12-1731 at S. Tomé; 2 seafarers and 1 soldier ran away. Laid up at Batavia in 1736.
From 08-07 till 16-07-1731 at S. Tiago; from 01-09 till 14-09-1731 at S. Tomé.
The master died and was succeeded by Pieter Jonges.
At S. Tiago from 11-09 till 26-09-1731. Acc. to K.A. 2100 the master was Jurriaan Lijssen. He probably succeeded Evert Vlaming.
At S. Tiago from 16-09 till 26-09-1731.
From 05-12 till 08-12-1731 at Portsmouth.
From 02-12 till 08-12-1731 at Duins. The ship arrived at Ft. Dauphin on Madagascar on 01-06-1732; 4 seafarers ran away there. Laid up at Batavia on 17-04-1733.
Back at Goeree from 29-1 1 till 11-12-1731. From 14-12-1731 till 01-01-1732 at Portsmouth.
Laid up at Batavia in 1740.
At Duins from 22-12 till 31-12-1731.
At Portsmouth from 15-12-1731 till 15-01-1732: 5 seafarers deserted. One soldier became seafarer.
At Duins from 22-12 till 31-12-1731.
From 22-12 till 31-12-1731 at Duins.
From 11-01 till 14-01-1732 at Duins: one seafarer went to the WESTERDIJKSHORN (2868).
At Duins from 11-01 till 14-01-1732.
At Duins from 11-01 till 14-01-1732.
At Duins from 11-01 till 14-01-1732; 1 soldier and 1 seafarer died there. Laid up at Batavia on 07-07-1741.
Laid up at Batavia in 1736.
From 29-02 till 07-03-1732 at S. Tiago: one soldier died and one soldier ran away.
At Plymouth from 29-01 till 15-03-1732: 3 seafarers deserted and two seafarers died there.

At S. Tiago from 20-06 till 26-06-1732: 3 seafarers and 3 soldiers ran away; 25 seafarers, 22 soldiers and one passenger from the SLOT TER HOGE (2877) came aboard. The ship was wrecked at Gale on 23-10-1735.
At Portsmouth from 24-05 till 30-05-1732. At S. Tiago from O5-07 till 14-07-1732; 6 soldiers from SLOT TER HOGE (2877) came aboard. Laid up at Batavia on 04-07-1738.
At Portsmouth from 25-05 till 30-05-1732. At S. Tiago from O5-07 till 14-07-1732. 4 Seafarers and 2 soldiers from the SLOT TER HOGE (2877) came aboard there.
At S. Tiago from 21-06 till 26-06-1732; from SLOT TER HOGE (2877) 26 seafarers and 16 soldiers came aboard.
The ship was at first called WALCHEREN, but it was renamed. At S. Tiago from 20-06 till 26-06-1732. On 28-03-1733 28 men went over to the HERSTELLING (2855).
Wrecked at Rembang in 1737.
Back at Texel from 10-11 till 13-11-1732.
Back at Texel from 08-11 till 13-11-1732.
Back at Texel from 09-11 till 13-11-1732.
Laid up at Batavia in 1740.
Back at Texel from 08-11 till 13-11-1732.
Back at Texel from 08-11 till 13-11-1732. Laid up at Batavia on 12-09-1738.
On 02-12-1732 at Rammekens; from now on the VOORDUIN was called ZORGWIJK (2920).

On account of a bad state the ship was sold at Lisbon on 01-02-1733. The EENDRACHT (now called NIEUWE VIS) (2925) took over the cargo on 08-09-1733. 37 Seafarers, 9 soldiers and 5 craftsmen deserted at Lisbon.
From 19-02 till 24-02-1733 at S. Tiago: 3 seafarers and 1 soldier ran away.
From 15-03 till 15-04-1733 at Plymouth.
From 05-02 till 21-03-1733 at Falmouth; 1 seafarer died there.
From 05-02 till 21-03-1733 at Falmouth; 6 seafarers died there. On 12-09-1738 laid up at Batavia.
From 05-02 till 21-03-1733 at Falmouth; 1 seafarer ran away there.
From 21-04- till 01-05-1733 at S. Tiago: 2 seaferers from SLOT TER HOGE (2877) came aboard.
One soldier became a seafarer.
From 02-07 till 10-07-1733 at Guinea: 1 seafarer deserted. Wrecked at Bantam in September 1740.
From 20-08-till 17-10-1733 at Saldanha Bay.
At Duins from 29-04 till 02-05-1733.
At the Cape the master went over to the VAN ALSEM (2921); he was succeeded by Dirk van Gunster.
Jan Hokkeling remained at the Cape and was succeeded by Jan Mijndertsz.
At the Cape Evert Kiekebos succeeded Van der Graaf. At Duins from 09-07 till 12-07-1733. Laid up at Batavia on 06-10-1741.
This ship was at first called EENDRACHT. Took over the cargo of the VIS (2898) at Lisbon; left on 15-10-1733. Data of those on board concern departure from Lisbon.
At Lisbon from 08-09 till 15-10-1733; 16 seafarers and 16 soldiers went to the NIEUWE VIS (2925).
1 Seafarer went to the KERKWIJK (2932).
1 Soldier became a seafarer.
One seafarer and one soldier went over to the WESTKAPELLE (2942); two seafarers from the WESTKAPELLE and the MEIJENBURG (2938) came on board.
Three seafarers went over to the EVERSWAART (2936), the VLISSINGEN (2941) and the WESTKAPELLE (2942) respectively.
Laid up at Batavia on 17-04-1739.
One seafarer went over to the STEENHOVEN (2940). One soldier became a seafarer. One soldier went over to the WESTKAPELLE (2942) and from the WESTKAPELLE one seafarer came on board.
One seafarer went over to the EVERSWAART (2936), five seafarers came on board from the VLISSINGEN (2941), the STEENHOVEN (2940), the MEIJENBURG (2938), and the EVERSWAART.
Johannes Karsteman died and was succeeded by Kornelis van der Hoeve.
One soldier became a seafarer.
From 17-03 till 17-04-1734 at Duins.
From 17-03 till 17-04 at Portsmouth: 1 seafarer deserted; 1 soldier became a seafarer; 1 seafarer came from DEN DAM (2952).
One seafarer went over to the SCHONAUWEN (2953); 1 soldier became a seafarer.
Wrecked near the Chinese coast on its outward bound voyage to China.
One soldier became a seafarer. One seafarer went to the IEPENBURG (2949). The ship was laid up at Batavia on 18-09-1742.
One soldier became a seafarer.
One soldier became a seafarer. From 21-06 till 30-06-1734 at S.Tiago: two soldiers deserted. On 25-12-1734 at Robben Island. Dirk Goudberg succeeded De Reus.
At S. Tiago from 21-07 till 31-07-1734.
At S. Tomé from 03-09 till 11-09-1734: 1 seafarer ran away.
From 21-07 till 31-07-1734 at S. Tiago; at Saldanha Bay from 16-10 till 31-10-1734.
At S. Tiago from 02-08 till 07-08-1734. Two soldiers came on board from the MEERLUST (2954).
From 09-07 till 18-07-1734 at Portsmouth; from 15-08 till 21 -OS-1734 at S. Tiago; from 09-11 till 21-11-1734 at Saldanha Bay.
From 13-09 till 02-11-1734 at Plymouth: 9 men deserted.
From 12-12 till 21-12-1734 at S. Tiago.
From 16-02 till 15-03-1735 at Saldanha Bay.
At Robben Island 21-02-1735. Wrecked on 10-03-1740 at the island of Watubela near Banda.
From 14-04 till 21-04 at S. Tiago where 1 seafarer deserted.
From 10-02 till 04-03 and 09-03 till 20-03 at Portsmouth where 2 seafarers deserted. 2976/6978 is the third voyage of the VOORDUIN, which during its first voyage (2817/6844) was called ZORGWIJK.
Wrecked at departure on 03-02-1735.
From 16 till 18-03-1735 at Duins.
From 16 till 18-03-1735 at Duins from 13-04 till 19-05-1735 at Lisbon where 10 seafarers and 5 soldiers deserted.
From 09 till 20-03-1735 at Portsmouth where 4 seafarers deserted.
From 16 till 18-03-1735 at Duins.
From 02 till 25-08 at Saldanha Bay. Laid up in the Indies on 01-03-1743.
One of the soldiers became ondermeester.
Laid up in the Indies on 03-12-1743.
From 07 till 15-06 at S. Tiago. One of the corporals became third meester.
From 07 till 15-06 at S. Tiago.
From 24-06 till 18-07-1735 at Portsmouth; from 19 till 25-09-1735 at S. Tiago. One of the soldiers became a seafarer.
One of the soldiers became cook's wain.
One of the soldiers became cook's wain.
From 19-07 till 01-08 at Duins. From 14 till 25-09 at S. Tiago where 4 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted.
Jan de Jagerdied, Anthonie Uiterschouw became master. From 19 till 24-10 at Duins. The NIEUWVLIET replaced the ANNA CATHARINA (2977), wrecked in February 1735.
From 19 till 24-10 at Duins. The WESTKAPELLE replaced the 'T VLIEGEND HART (2978), wrecked in February 1735.
From 11 till 17-03 at Robben Island. One of the soldiers became cook's wain.
Two soldiers became third meesters.
From 29-11 till 05-12 at S. Tiago. One of the craftsmen became cooper. The three passengers included one female slave.
From 22 till 27-02 at S. Tiago.
From 16 till 18-01-1736 at Duins; from 19 till 22-01 at Portsmouth. The BOOT (3008) took over one of the seafarers of the SLOT KRONENBURG. The five passengers included two female slaves.
From 18-01 till 18-02 at Duins: one seafarer was taken over by the VLISSINGEN (3011); from 19 till 25-02 at Portsmouth.
From 18-01 till 18-02 at Duins: the ship took over one seafarer of the MEIJENBURG (3010), two soldiers died; from 19 till 22-02 at Portsmouth; 2 soldiers and 2 craftsmen deserted.

From 13 till 18-02-1736 the ship was back at Texel. On 19-02-1736 it stranded on Goodwin's Sand; 102 seafarers, 44 soldiers and 9 craftsmen deserted or died; the crew was completed with 111 seafarers and 28 soldiers; on the fifth of May 1736 the ship departed from Duins in a damaged condition.
One of the soldiers became cook's wain. The CASTRICUM was laid up in the Indies on 19-03-1743.
From 13 till 18-02 the ship was back at Texel.
One of the soldiers became cook's wain.
From 14 till 18-02-1736 the ship was back at Texel.

From 13 till 19-02-1736 the ship was back at Texel; from 26-02 till 26-03 it was at Plymouth: 9 seafarers and 3 soldiers deserted. From 02 till 05-08 the VREELAND was at Saldanha Bay. One of the soldiers became cook, another became seafarer.

Originally, on the fifteenth of March 1736 at Goeree, the crew was composed as is indicated in the first column, but before the final departure of the PAPENBURG on 06-05-1736 the crew was reduced to 144 seafarers, 83 soldiers and 10 craftsmen. From 27 till 29-05-1736 the ship was at Duins, from 05 till 13-09 at Saldanha Bay.
From 27 till 29-05-1736 at Duins.
From 22 till 29-05-1736 at Duins.
From 22 till 29-05-1736 at Duins.
From 11 till 18-07-1736 at S. Tiago. Laid up in the Indies, 01-03-1743.
From 09 till 11-06-1736 at Duins; from 18 till 25-07 at S. Tiago: 2 soldiers deserted.
The 12 passengers included four slaves (two males and two females).
From 19 till 25-07-1736 at S. Tiago.
Jan van Riet remained at the Cape, Huibrecht Bout became master. From 17-07 till 28-07-1736 the DISHOEK was at Portsmouth, from 07-12 till 20-12-1736 at Soango Boanie in Angola.
From 21 till 25-08-1736 at S. Tiago: 7 seafarers and 2 soldiers deserted; one new seafarer was taken on board.
Laid up in the Indies, 31-12-1747.

From 19-05 till 28-05-1737 the CORNELIA was at S. Tiago: 6 seafarers and 3 soldiers deserted, one soldier became seafarer; from 21-10 till 06-11-1736 the ship was at Saldanha Bay. One of the passengers was a former slave.
One of the passengers who embarked at the Cape was a slave.
Three of the passengers were indicated as 'blacks'.
From 02-06 till 09-06-1737 the ship was at S. Tiago : one seafarer deserted.
During the voyage one soldier became a seafarer.
The passengers included one female slave.
During the voyage one soldier became a seafarer. From 02-08 till 02-09-1737 the PALLAS was at Simon Bay, a part of False Bay.
According to KA 2288, the RIDDERKERK was wrecked in 1743 at Conati in Persia.
During the voyage one craftsman became a seafarer.
From 17-04 till 29-04-1737 the WATERVLIET was at S. Tiago. Two soldiers became seafarers.
3059/7014 Is the third voyage of the ZORGWIJK, which during its first voyage (see 2896/-) was called VOORDUIN.
During the voyage one of the soldiers became a seafarer. The passengers included 11 slaves (6 males and 5 females).
From 23-06 till 08-07-1737 the ship was at Saldanha Bay.
During the voyage one of the soldiers became a seafarer. The passengers who embarked at the Cape included eight slaves: two (married) couples with two children each.
Laid up at Ceylon, 12-01-1740. One of the passengers was a slave.
From 04 till 11-05-1737 the ship was at Duins. One of the soldiers became bottler.
From 09 till 24-07-1737 the ship was at St. Tiago: the crew was enlarged with 2 seafarers.
From 22-06 till 02-07-1737 the ship was at St. Tiago: the crew was enlarged with one seafarer (see 3074).

Christiaan Bakker died during the voyage, Jakob Hendrik Inker succeeded him as master. From 23-06 till 02-07 the ship was at St. Tiago: the DUIFJE (3073) took over the second cooper. From 27-10 till 07-11-1737 the SCHONAUWEN was at Saldanha Bay.
From 13 till 23-07-1737 the SCHELLAG was at S. Tiago: 1 seafarer and 2 soldiers died or deserted, the reduced crew was enlarged with one soldier.
From 31-07 till 06-08-1737 the ship was at S. Tiago. During the voyage one soldier became a seafarer. One stowaway was found on the POPKENSBURG.
From 23 till 26-08-1 737 the ship was at S. Tiago. During the voyage one soldier became a seafarer.
From 22 till 26-08-1737 the ship was at S. Tiago.
From 22 till 26-08-1737 the ship was at S. Tiago.
From 23-09 till 15-10-1737 the ship was at Falmouth.
From 23-09 till 15-10-1737 the ship was at Falmouth: 2 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted. The HOF NIET ALTIJD ZOMER was laid up in the Indies, 11-06-1743.
One seafarer was taken over by the KASTEEL VAN TILBURG (3087); one of the soldiers became a seafarer. The two 'passengers' were slaves.
From 20 till 25-10-1737 the ship was at Portsmouth: one seafarer deserted.
During the voyage one of the soldiers became a seafarer, another soldier became cook. The two 'passengers' were slaves.
From 20 till 25-10-1737 the ship was at Portsmouth. During the voyage 1 craftsman and 2 soldiers became seafarers.

At least two, and probably even three soldiers became seafarers. The ship took over one seafarer from the BERKENRODE (see 3083); the BERKENRODE took over one seafarer from the KASTEEL VAN TILBURG. One of the passengers was a slave.
Adriaan Katersveld died during the voyage, Wijnand van Nullerus succeeded him as master. During the voyage one of the soldiers became seafarer.
From 14 till 30-03-1738 the ship was at S. Tiago: one seafarer deserted.
From 30-11 till 05-12-1737 the ship was at S. Tiago: one seafarer deserted.
During the voyage one seafarer deserted, one of the soldiers became seafarer.
During the voyage one of the soldiers became seafarer.
From 21-01 till 20-02-1738 the ship was at Plymouth: one seafarer deserted.
From 15 till 30-03-1738 the ship was at S. Tiago. One soldier and one craftsman became seafarers.
During the voyage Herman Blom died; Pieter Elsvliet succeeded him as master. From 15-01 till 15-02-1738 the ship was at Plymouth: one seafarer deserted.
From 13 till 28-01-1738 the ship was at Portsmouth.
Initially the ship departed from Texel on 01-01-1738, but three days later it returned. From 13-01 till 20-02-1738 the POLANEN was at Plymouth. During the voyage two soldiers became seafarers.

From 13-01 till 17-02-1738 the ship was at Portsmouth. During the voyage one of the soldiers became seafarer. The MEIJENBURG was laid up in the Indies, 12-06-1744. (The numbers in the second and fifth column include small numbers of deserters.)
From 13-01 till 17-02-1738 the ship was at Portsmouth: 2 seafarers deserted. The passengers included 3 slaves (one male and two females). The STEENHOVEN was wrecked on a voyage to Bandain 1741.

The initial date of departure of the HILVERSBEEK was 01-01-1738, but 25 days later it returned to Texel. From 20 till 30-03-1738 the ship was at S. Tiago. During the voyage two soldiers became seafarers.
From 27-04 till 04-05 the ship was at S. Tiago: two seafarers and one soldier deserted.
From 27-04 till 01-05-1738 the ship was at S. Tiago: one seafarer and one craftsman deserted. The NOORDWIJKERHOUT was laid up in the Indies, 11-09-1744.

The initial date of departure was 01-01, but on 10-02 the ship was back at Terschelling; it sailed off again on the 25th of that month, but returned on 04-03 once more to Texel; before its third and final date of departure, 27-03, one seafarer deserted. From 06 till 14-06 the ship was at S. Tiago: the crew was enlarged with 2 seafarers; one soldier became a seafarer. The PROOSTWIJK was laid up in the Indies, 02-08-1743. See also 3110.
Daniel van Staden did not survive the voyage, Joost Salomonsz. Anker succeeded him as master.

20-04-1738 Was the final date of departure of the NIEUWSTAD; an earlier departure took place in 1737. During the last stay of the ship at Texel, 30-01 till 20-04, the crew was enlarged with 11 seafarers. From 03 till 14-06 the ship was at S. Tiago: 1 seafarer was taken over by the PROOSTWIJK (3107), one of the soldiers became a seafarer.
The HUIS TE SPIJK did not call at the Cape, but at False Bay (13-08 til!07-09): two seafarers left the ship, see the third column.
3112/7095 Is the fourth voyage of the VOORDUIN, which during its first voyage (2817/6844) was called ZORGWIJK. From 20-09 till 02-10-1738 the ship was at Saldanha Bay; one soldier became seafarer.
One of the passengers was a female slave.
During the voyage one soldier became seafarer.
During the voyage two soldiers became seafarers.
From 21-06 till 01-07-1738 the ship was at S. Tiago. During the voyage one of the cooks became soldier.
Two of the passengers on the PAPENBURG were female slaves. From 20-06 till 01-07 the ship was at S. Tiago. Besides the 62 persons indicated in the third column two stowaways disembarked at the Cape.
On its way to the Cape the COXHOORN called at Duins (27-05 till 07-06-1738) and at S. Tiago (16 till 23-07-1738).
From 11-06 till 11-07-1738 the ship was at Duins. During a stay at S. Tiago, 23-08 till 04-09-1738, five soldiers deserted.
During the voyage one soldier became seafarer.
From 06 till 10-11-1738 the ship was at Duins.
The three passengers included two 'black passengers'. During the voyage two soldiers became seafarers.
The PAREL was laid up in the Indies, 31-12-1747.
The SLOT KRONENBURG was laid up in the Indies, 11-09-1744.
During a long stay at Portsmouth (09-01 till 23-03-1739) 2 seafarers, 12 soldiers and 1 craftsman deserted.
From 10-01 till 22-03-1739 the ship was at Falmouth: 2 seafarers deserted. During the voyage one soldier became seafarer. The MIDDENRAK was laid up in the Indies, 11-09-1744. See also 3139.
The WATERVLIET called at Portsmouth twice (10-01 till 10-03 and 16 till 27-03-1739); during the second stay at Portsmouth one seafarer was added to the crew; one of the soldiers became seafarer.
One soldier was taken over by the MIDDENRAK (3136).

From 23-02 till 11 -03-1 739 the ship was back at Texel. Two days after its final departure (11-03) the NIEUWERKERK called at Duins (13-till 23-03): one seafarer deserted. The ship also called at Portsmouth (25-03 till 06-04) and at Torbay (08 till 15-04-1739); at Torbay one seafarer was taken over by the GAASPERDAM (3138). One of the passengers was indicated as a 'black boy'.
During the voyage one soldier became seafarer.
Kornelis van de Woestijne did not survive the voyage, Bastiaan Koleman succeeded him as master.
From 29-07 till 06-08-1739 the ship was at Robben Island. One of the soldiers became seafarer.
During the voyage one soldier became seafarer.
3149/- Is the fourth voyage of the ZORGWIJK, which during its first voyage (see 2896/-) was called VOORDUIN. The ship was laid up in the Indies, 11-09-1744. One of the passengers was a female slave.

From 13 till 20-07-1739 the ship was at S. Tiago: one seafarer and three soldiers deserted. 
Since 22-09-1740 the STREEFKERK was missing at the island 'Cureduvo at Calpetty'.
From 13 till 21-07-1739 the ship was at S. Tiago. During the voyage one soldier became seafarer.
From 18 till 24-06-1739 the ship was at S. Tiago: 2 seafarers deserted; the crew was enlarged with one soldier. The nine passengers included three female slaves and a slave-child.
From 16 till 23-07-1739 the ship was at S. Tiago. One soldier became seafarer. The six passengers included three slaves (one male and two females).
Joris Davidson died on the way; Christiaan Duif succeeded him as master. One soldier became seafarer. One of the passengers was a female slave.
The LAGEPOLDER was sold at Batavia, 28-03-1747.
On its way to the Cape the ship called at Duins: from 09 till 11-10-1739.
From 09 till 11-10-1739 the ship was at Duins.
The ship called at Duins from 09 till 10-10-1739.
On 14-01-1740 the SCHEIJBEEK arrived at Robben Island.
The PHOENIX was laid up at Batavia on 16-09-1746.
The VREELAND arrived at Robben Island on 17-01-1740.
One soldier became seafarer; one of the seafarers was taken over by the WICKENBURG (see 3169). According to a letter from Bengal (31-12-1743) the MAGDALENA was laid up there.
During the voyage three seafarers deserted; the crew was enlarged by one seafarer, taken over from the MAGDALENA (see 3168), and a sailmaker.
During the voyage one soldier became seafarer.
The VIS was wrecked 'behind the Waterplaats' at the Cape on 06-05-1740.
The two passengers on the HOF VAN DELFT were slaves.
During the voyage Kornelis Mol died, Willem Hendriksz. van Roffe succeeded him as master. One of the soldiers became seafarer.

3179/- Is the seventh voyage of this ship, which during its preceding six voyages was called KASTEEL VAN WOERDEN (3114/7072). From 23-06 till 06-07-1740 the ship was at S. Tiago, where 6 seafarers deserted and one soldier probably became seafarer.
From 22-06 till 06-07-1740 the ship was at S. Tiago.

The ship called at S. Tiago (23-06 till 06-07-1740). One soldier became seafarer. 3181/7143 Is the fifth voyage of this ship, which during its four preceding voyages was called WAPEN VAN HOORN (see 3109/7070).
From 30-11-1740 till 02-01-1741 the ship was at Cape Lopez; it also called at Saldanha Bay (20-04 till 02-05-1741). The ship was sold at Batavia on 10-12-1747.
From 01 till 06-07-1740 the ship wat at S. Tiago, where one member of the crew deserted, probably a seafarer. In 1745 the HILLEGONDA was laid up at Batavia.
From 27-06 till 06-07-1740 the ship was at Porto Prayo and from 18-10 till 02-11 it called at Saldanha Bay.
Dirk Pomp died during the voyage; Christian Boelhouwer succeeded him as master. The ship called at S. Tiago from 29-08 till 03-09-1740.

The 48 persons indicated in the fifth column include 12 seafarers and 8 soldiers who disembarked during a long stay at Pernambuco (13-09 till 13-11-1740); they all went to the hospital there. 2 Soldiers became seafarers.
3188/7146 Is the second voyage of the KASTEEL VAN WOERDEN; during the preceding voyage (3077/7057) it was called BUVEGNIES. From 29-07 till 11-08-1740 the ship was at S. Tiago.
Two soldiers probably became seafarers.

26-09-1740 Was the final date of departure of the CORNELIA; on 05-01-1740 it sailed out for the first time, but on 19-03 it returned to Texel. During the voyage one soldier became seafarer. The ship was laid up in the Indies on 11-09-1744.
From 15 till 26-10-1740 the ship called at Portsmouth. One of the soldiers became corporal, another soldier probably became seafarer.
One of the 17 seafarers who embarked at the Cape was taken over from the AMSTERDAM (see 3194); one soldier probably became seafarer. The five passengers included one former slave.
During the voyage one soldier became cook's wain.
One of the 20 seafarers who disembarked at the Cape was taken over by the WESTKAPELLE (3192). During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer.
3196/- Is the seventh voyage of this ship, which during its six preceding voyages was called   HOGERSMILDE (see 3078/7056). The ship was laid up in the Indies on 11-09-1744.
The THEEKOP was laid up and sold at Batavia on 1748.
The DIEMERMEER called at Duins (09 till 16-11-1740). One soldier probably became seafarer.
Two soldiers probably became seafarers.
Adverse winds forced the ship to call at Duins (06 till 26-01-1741). One soldier probably became seafarer.
From 02 till 26-01-1741 the ship was at Duins.
One soldier became bottler's mate.

The LEIDUIN called at S. Tiago where one seafarer and one soldier deserted (05 till 30-03-1741). Some of the four seafarers who embarked at the Cape were taken over from the PATMOS (3207); at the Cape three soldiers became seafarers. The ship was laid up in the Indies on 11-09-1744.

The ship called at S. Tiago where it arrived on 09-03-1741 (date of departure is unknown). 3208/- Is the fifth voyage of the VOORDUIN, which during its first voyage (2817/6844) was called ZORGWIJK. The ship was laid up in the Indies on 26-01-1745.

From 03 till 08-03-1741 the RUITER was at Mountsbay where 4 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted. From 10 till 22-05-1741 the ship called at Plymouth where 17 seafarers and 3 soldiers died and 11 seafarers and 7 soldiers deserted. The diminished crew was enlarged by 37 seafarers from Amsterdam. The ship also called at S. Tiago (04 till 17-07-1741) where 1 seafarer and 1 soldier deserted and 2 soldiers became seafarers.
After an accident on a voyage to Ambon the DELFLAND was laid up on 12-07-1746.
One soldier probably became seafarer.
The DUIFJE was sold at Batavia on 28-03-1747.
The OOSTERHOUT called at S. Tiago (16 till 26-06-1741) and at Saldanha Bay (13-12-1741 till 08-02-1742). See also 3214. The ship was laid up at Batavia on 16-04-1748.

From 04 till 17-07-1741 the ship called at S. Tiago where one seafarer, deserted from the OOSTERHOUT (3213), embarked. One soldier probably became seafarer. The ship was laid up in the Indies on 25-02-1746.
The VLISSINGEN called at S. Tiago (06 till 17-07-1741) and at Robben Island (27 till 30-10-1741).
From 06 till 17-07-1741 the WESTHOVEN was at S. Tiago and from 27-10 till 02-11-1741 it was at Dassen Island.
From 05-11 till 07-12-1741 the MEERLUST called at Saldanha Bay. One soldier probably became seafarer.
The IDA called at Robben Island (05 till 16-11-1741).
During the voyage two soldiers probably became seafarers.
During the voyage one seafarer probably became soldier. The NOORDWOLFSBERGEN was sold at Batavia on 10-11-1747.
The TOLSDUIN called at S. Tiago (14 till 26-12-1741).
During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer.
The ship was laid up at Batavia on 01-11-1752.
During the voyage two soldiers probably became seafarers. One source mentions Hammen Noordrecht as master.
The PALLAS called at S. Tiago (24-12-1741 till 01-01-1742). During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer. The ship was sold at Batavia on 25-04-1747.
The KNAPPENHOF called at Duins (21-12-1741 till 02-01-1742).
The VREELAND called at Portsmouth (19 till 23-12-1741). Three soldiers became seafarers.
The HORSSEN was laid up in the Indies on 15-08-1749. In one source Pieter Aas is mentioned as master.
The DUINENBURG did not call at the Cape, but at False Bay.
During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer. The NIEUWVLIET was laid up at Batavia on 23-07-1750.

The SARA JACOBA called at Saldanha Bay (25-06 till 01-08-1742) where 9 seafarers and 4 soldiers died. The six passengers who embarked at the Cape included ex-Governor-General Adriaan Valkenier, arrested at the Cape after his return from Batavia in January 1742 (see also 7130); he was accused by the future Governor-General Van Imhoff of being reponsible for the notorious 'Chinese murders' in Batavia in 1740.
The HOF VAN DELFT did not call at the Cape, but af False Bay.
On 01-09-1746 the ship exploded on the roads of Batavia.
One soldier probably became seafarer.
One soldier became seafarer.
One seafarer became soldier.
From 08 till 11-09-1742 the POLANEN was at Robben Island. At the Cape two soldiers became cook and cook's wain; another soldier probably became seafarer.
The EVERSWAART called at Robben Island (07 till 11-09-1742). At the Cape one soldier became cook. The ship was laid up at Batavia on 03-12-1748.

The ANNA called at Madeira (12 till 14-11-1742) and at S. Tiago (25/6-11-1742). During the voyage, probably at the Cape, one seafarer was taken over by the EENDRACHT (3254); five soldiers became seafarers.
The EENDRACHT called at Madeira (12 till 14-1 1-1742) and at S. Tiago (25/6-11-1742). See also 3253.
The FORTUIN called at Madeira (12 till 14-11-1742) and at S. Tiago (25/6-11-1742). At the Cape 2 seafarers disembarked, another deserted; the 14 passengers who embarked at the Cape included 4 slaves.

The HERSTELDER, previously called EDAM, had been bought by the VOC from the Admiralty of Amsterdam. The 9 passengers included Governor-General Van Imhoff and 7 servants. From 12 till 14-11-1742 the ship called at Madeira where 2 seafarers embarked. The ship also called at S. Tiago (25/6-11-1742) where 1 seafarer died. At the Cape 3 seafarers and 1 servant of the GG became soldiers.
From 05 till 21-11-1742 the SCHELLAG was at Portsmouth.
The ZAAMSLAG called at Portsmouth (05 till 21-11-1742) and at S. Tiago (15 till 20-12-1742) where 11 persons died and 13 soldiers deserted.
The ADRICHEM was sold at Batavia on 06-04-1747. In one source Jakob van der Stoel is mentioned as master.
During the voyage one seafarer became soldier. The HOFVLIET replaced the WATERVLIET, wrecked in May 1742 (see 3248).
Two seafarers were taken over by an English man-of-war. Anthonie Marijnissen died during the voyage.
From 30-04 till 13-05-1743 the ship was at S. Tiago . At the Cape one soldier became seafarer.
From 30-04 till 13-05-1743 the ship called at S. Tiago, where 2 soldiers died.
One source mentions Pieter Schildman as master.

The LOVERENDAAL called at Duins from 11 till 27-04-1743 where at Duins 10 seafarers deserted, one soldier died and the crew was enlarged by one seafarer; 2 soldiers became seafarers. The ship was laid up at Batavia on 13-12-1751.
The 16 seafarers who disembarked at the Cape included 3 deserters.
From 15 till 20-06-1743 the ship was at S. Tiago. See also 3265.
The RUYVEN called at Duins from 28-06 till 01-07-1743. On 11-09-1745 the ship was wrecked on the Ganges.
From 20 till 29-08-1743 the HEUVEL was at S. Tiago. The ship replaced the ENKHUIZEN, lost in 1742 (see 7138).
From 19 till 29-08-1743 the ship was at S. Tiago where the crew was enlarged by 2 seafarers. During the voyage 2 soldiers became seafarers.
The VERWACHTING was lost in 1744 on a voyage from China to Surat.
The HUIGENWAARD called at Saldanha Bay, where one craftsman died.
On its way to the Cape the AKERENDAM called at Duins (30-10 till 28-11-1743) and at S. Tiago (29-12-1743 till 05-01-1744). At S. Tiago one soldier deserted.
From 18 till 19-11-1743 the DUINHOF was at Duins.
The RUST EN WERK called at Duins (01 till 14-11-1743) and at S. Tiago (13 till 22-01-1744).
The BOSBEEK called at Portsmouth (25 till 31-12-1743) where 8 seafarers deserted. During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer.
At the Cape 6 soldiers probably became seafarers.
One week after its departure from Texel the ship returned (04-12-1743); on 27-12 it sailed out again. The HUIS TE MARQUETTE was sold at Batavia on 10-11-1747.

On its way to the Cape the ship called at Duins (08-till 13-12-1743) where 2 seafarers deserted, at Dassen Island (17-02 till 06-03-1744), and at Saldanha Bay. During the voyage one soldier probably became seafarer.
The TOLSDUIN called at Duins (17-12-1743 till 06-01-1744) where 11 seafarers and 4 soldiers were pressed by the English. During the voyage one soldier became seafarer.
At the Cape one stowaway, not registered in the columns, disembarked; one soldier became third meester (counted as seafarer).
From 02 till 04-02-1744 the DISHOEK called at S. Tiago where one seafarer died, another seafarer and one soldier deserted.

The passengers who embarked at Rammekens included one female slave. From 06 till 18-02-1744 the ship was at S. Tiago where one seafarer was taken over by the RUITER (see 3296). 7 Condemned criminals embarked, two of them died on the way to Batavia.
From 04 till 16-02-1744 the JONGE WILLEM was at S. Tiago where two seafarers died and six soldiers deserted. The ship was laid up in the Indies on 03-06-1749.
09-01-1744 Was the final date of departure of the SIJBEKARSPEL; on 01-01-1744 the ship set out for the first time, but four days later it returned to Texel.

From 07 till 18-02-1744 the RUITER called at S. Tiago where one seafarer and five soldiers died; the crew was enlarged by one seafarer, taken over from the OUWERKERK (see 3293), and one soldier. At the Cape ten seafarers deserted. The ship was laid up in the Indies on 03-06-1749.
During the voyage one soldier became seafarer. The seven passengers were criminals. The NIEUW VIJVERVREUGD exploded in 1746 on the roads of Batavia.
From 07 till 10-07-1744 the ship was at S. Tiago. One of the soldiers became cook's wain. The 2 seafarers who embarked at the Cape included a master, Kornelis Booys.
The KETEL called at Portsmouth from 06-08 till 09-12-1744. See also 3313. According to a Resolution of Gouverneur-Generaal en Raden the ship was sold to Spanish merchants at Manila in 1748.
The VOORZICHTIGHEID did not call at the Cape but at Saldanha Bay.

One day after its departure the ship returned to Goeree (07-11-1744); it finally set out on 08-12-1744. From 29-12-1744 till 26-01-1745 the ship called at Duins. The HUIS TE PERSIJN did not call at the Cape, but at False Bay (25-05 till 11-06-1745). During the voyage 4 soldiers became seafarers.

Four days after its departure the ship returned to Texel (10-11-1744); it finally sailed out on 09-12. The eight passengers included one female slave. The HOP VAN DELFT was sold in the Indies on 17-02-1750.
Four days after its departure the DIEMEN returned to Texel (10-11-1744); it finally set out on 09-12-1744. The ship carried f 250,000 in cash.

Four days after its departure the ship returned to Texel (10-11-1744); it finally departed on 09-12. The EENDRACHT called at Robben Island (04 till 07-03-1745). The ship carried f 250,000 in cash. The passenger who embarked at the Cape was a stowaway found on the returning TOLSDUIN (see 7208). Nanning Breeder died, his successor is unknown.
The ZAAMSLAG returned to Texel on 10-11;  it finally departed on 09-12-1744. The ship carried f 200,000 in cash.
The ZUIDERBURG returned to Texel on 10-11; its final date of departure was 09-12-1744. The ship carried f 250,000 in cash.

Some of the 29 persons who disembarked at the Cape went to the KETEL (see 3304); the 16 embarking persons partially came from the KETEL and the LEIDEN (see 3321). One soldier became cook's wain. The BROUWER replaced the ABBEKERK, wrecked on a return voyage in 1742 (see 7139).
At the Cape one seafarer turned out to be a woman; she continued the voyage as passenger. One soldier became cook's wain. The DOMBURG carried f 250,000 in cash.
From 20 till 23-01-1745 the ship was at S. Tiago. One of the craftsmen became bottler's mate. The SPANDERSWOUD carried f 100,000 in cash.
The HUIS TE SPIJK was laid up and sold at Batavia on 18-07-1752.

From 02 till 13-03-1745 the SCHELLAG was at S. Tiago: at Porto Prayo the crew was enlarged with 16 seafarers and 27 soldiers. These 43 persons came from the SCHONAUWEN (see 3320). The ship carried f 100,000 in cash. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.

14-01-1745 Was the final date of departure of the VREELAND; on 06-12-1744 the ship sailed out for the first time, it returned to Texel the same day however. The ship called at Torbay (24 till 29-01-1745) and at Plymouth (05 till 26-02-1745). It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay; the two passengers who embarked there included one slave. The VREELAND was laid up at Batavia on 10-11-1750.

From 07 till 13-03-1745 the SCHONAUWEN was at S. Tiago: 16 seafarers and 27 soldiers were taken over by the SCHELLAG (see 3318). The SCHONAUWEN did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. The ship was sold at Batavia on 29-01-1754.
At the Cape one seafarer was taken over by the BROUWER (see 3313), another disembarked.
The HARTENLUST did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 11-05-1753.

Six days before the IDA reached the Cape 20 seaferers and 11 soldiers were taken over from the DUINENBURG (see 3331). The ship was laid up in the Indies on 11-05-1751. Klaas van den Hoed and Jakob van der Meer are also mentioned in sources as master of the IDA.
From 21-05 till 09-06-1745 the NIEUWSTAD called at S. Tiago where 4 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted. At the Cape one seafarer turned out to be a woman; she continued the voyage as a passenger.
At the Cape two soldiers became seafarers. The GOIDSCHALXOORD was laid up at Batavia in 1750.
The RIJNHUIZEN was laid up at Batavia on 31-12-1751.
From 15 till 22-08-1745 the DUINENBURG called at S. Tiago. From 11 till 28-12-1745 the ship was at Saldanha Bay. See also the IDA (3325).
The HERSTELDER called at Saldanha Bay from 06 till 25-11-1745.
The LIS called at S. Tiago (19 till 29-09-1745): at Porto Prayo 3 seafarers and 3 soldiers deserted. The ship also called at Robben Island (29 till 31-12-1745).
From 03 till 13-10-1745 the HOF D'UNO called at S. Tiago where one seafarer and four soldiers deserted.

From 14 till 22-09 the WESTHOVEN was at Portsmouth where 6 seafarers and 4 soldiers were pressed by the English. The ship also called at Dassen Island from 06 till 18-01-1746. The passenger who embarked at the Cape was a stowaway , found on the REIGERSDAAL (see 7230).

The NIEUWERKERK called at Duins from 10-10 till 14-11-1745 where 7 soldiers who had tried to desert were delivered to the DORDRECHT, a man-of-war; another soldier turned out to be a woman and was put on shore. The NIEUWERKERK was wrecked in 1748 on a voyage from Batavia to Banda. Francois Pennink and Reinier van der Luchten also are mentioned in sources as master of the NIEUWERKERK.
The FORTUIN carried f 150,000 in cash.
The LEKKERLAND carried f 250,000 in cash.
During the voyage, probably in November, 43 soldiers were taken over from the WILDRIJK (see 3343) and other ships. The SCHEIJBEEK carried f 200, 000 in cash.
The SARA JACOBA was laid up and sold at Batavia on 02-02-1753.
The WAAKZAAAMHEID called at S. Tiago from 21 till 26-01-1746.

15-12-1745 Was the final date of departure of the EINDHOEF; on 24-11-1745 the ship set out for the first time but four days later it returned: 20 soldiers disembarked and 30 seafarers were taken over from the HUIS TE RENSBURG (see 3353); the original crew consequently was altered into 83 seafarers and 21 soldiers.
The ZEELANDIA did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. On the way to Batavia one seafarer turned out to be a woman; she continued the voyage as a passenger.

Five days after its departure the ship returned to Texel (20-02-1746); it finally set out on 10-03-1746. From 05 till 09-04-1746 the GETROUWIGHEID called at S. Tiago. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.

The PATMOS was at S. Tiago from 02 till 10-05-1746. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. One source mentions Jan de Wever as master of the PATMOS. On 27-10-1752 the ship was wrecked at the reef 'na de Smalle Baei'.
The DISHOEK did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The KNAPPENHOF did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. The ship was sold at Batavia on 02-07-1754.

09-04-1746 Was the final date of departure of the HUIS TE RENSBURG; on 24-11-1745 it set out for the first time, but on 27-01-1746 it returned. Thirty seafarers had been taken over by the EINDHOEF (see 3346); the first column indicates the final composition of the crew. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The RUST EN WERK did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.

It is possible that initially Pieter Schildman was master and that he died before reaching the Cape. From 08 till 15-05-1746 the STANDVASTIGHEID was at Porto Prayo (S. Tiago). The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The four passengers included one slave. The TOLSDUIN called at S. Tiago (03 till 06-05-1746) and at False Bay.
The SLOT VAN KAPELLE did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. The ship carried f 225,000 in cash.
From 09 till 23-05-1746 the AKERENDAM was at Duins.
The two passengers were former slaves. From 09 till 23-05-1746 the BATAVIER was at Duins.

The MAARSSEVEEN called at Duins (09 till 23-05-1746) and at S. Tiago (10-06 till 12-07-1746), where the crew was enlarged by 9 French seafarers. In 1748 the ship exploded on a voyage from Banda to Batavia.
See also 3364. In 1751 the WESTKAPELLE was laid up at Bengal.
From 07 till 22-07-1746 the BOSBEEK called at S. Tiago, where four soldiers 'disembarked' (they probably died); the crew was enlarged by five French seafarers.
See also 3364.

The HUIS TEN DONK called at Duins (30-06 till 16-07-1746) and at S. Tiago (18 till 21-08-1746). Some of the 17 persons who disembarked at the Cape were taken over by the WESTKAPELLE (3361) and the OUWERKERK (3363).
From 28-06 till 06-07-1746 the ship was at Duins.
The SIJBEKARSPEL called at S. Tiago from 27-08 till 03-09-1746 where 3 French seafarers embarked. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 11-05-1753.
The OVERNES called at Portsmouth (05-08 till 21-08-1746 (?)) and at S. Tiago (08 till 14-09-1746).
From 13 till 26-10-1746 the GUSTAAF WILLEM called at S. Tiago. After the departure from the Cape two stowaways were found.
The BEUKESTIJN carried f 150,000 in cash. The ship was laid up and sold at Batavia on 11-05-1753.
During the voyage two soldiers became seafarers. The HAARLEM carried f 300,000 in cash.
From 20 till 26-02-1747 the HUIS TE MANPAD called at Robben Island. The ship carried f 250,000 in cash.
The OOSTKAPELLE called Robben Island from 03 till 13-02-1747.
From 03 till 13-02-1747 the NIEUW WALCHEREN called at Robben Island. The ship was wrecked on the roads of Surat on 24-05-1748.
Some of the 16 persons who disembarked at the Cape were taken over by the LEIDEN (see 3382).
Between the Cape and Batavia one soldier turned out to be a woman; she continued the voyage as a passenger.
The four passengers included two female slaves. The DIEMEN carried f 130,000 in cash.
Van Nimwegen was 'Commander of the Indian Sea'. From 30-12-1746 till 05-01-1747 the LEIDEN was at S. Tiago. The ship carried f 150,000 in cash.

Martin den Breems died; at the Cape he was succeeded by Pieter Pietersz. The 5 passengers included one slave. The ZUIDERBURG called at S. Tiago (31-12-1746 till 09-01-1747) and at Robben Island (17 till 19-03-1747). The ship carried f 150,000 in cash.
The OUD BERKENRODE did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. On 04-12-1747 the ship was wrecked 'in the Bight of Anjer'; most of the cargo and crew was saved.
The WELTEVREDEN did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The DOMBURG did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
From 31-03 till 07-04-1747 the DUINHOF was at S. Tiago. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The HAGEDIS did not call at the Cape but at False Bay and Simon's Bay (17-06 till 04-07-1747). The ship was sold at Batavia on 19-03-1748.
The BAARZANDE did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The HUIS TER DUINE did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
The JAGER called at S. Tiago (26-05 till 03-06-1747), at Bali (28-12-1747 till 25-01-1748), and at Lombok (28/9-01-1748).
In 1748 the HUIS TE PERSIJN was wrecked on a return voyage from Japan.
From 28-06 till 03-07-1747 the SCHAKENBOS was at S. Tiago.
The KLEVERSKERKE called at S. Tiago, where one seafarer disembarked, another one and one soldier deserted.
From 17-11 till 07-12-1747 the BROUWER called at Saldanha Bay.
From 05 till 13-09-1747 the ZAAMSLAG was at 'Goeree near Cape Verde'.
From 27-09 till 01-10-1747 the IMMAGONDA called at S. Tiago where 2 seafarers and 2 soldiers deserted.

The SCHELLAG called at S. Tiago from 22-09 till 01-10-1747 where one sailmaker was taken over by the IMMAGOND A (see 3404), another seafarer and 16 soldiers deserted. In 1748, during a return voyage from Japan, the ship was captured by the French.
From 25-12-1747 till 05-01-1748 the AMSTELVEEN called at S. Tiago. The ship carried f 150,000 in cash.
The SLOT VAN KAPELLE called at S. Tiago from 23-12 till O5-01 where 6 seafarers, 19 soldiers and one craftsman deserted. The ship carried f 150,000 in cash.
From 27-12-1747 till 05-01-1748 the ship called at S. Tiago. It carried f 100,000 in cash. The EINDHOEF was laid up and sold at Batavia on 31-12-1755.
The FORTUIN called at S. Tiago (23-11-1747 till 05-01-1748) where three soldiers deserted and one seafarer embarked. The ship carried f 100,000 in cash.
